Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Integrating the unique collections of southern Illinois at SIU to improve coverage of the Southeastern US Flora in SERNEC
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award the Southern Illinois University (SIU) Herbarium will join the SERNEC Thematic Collections Network (TCN). The SIU collections house an estimated 90,000 specimens of plants, primarily representing the regional flora, including many historically important specimens. While providing diverse data useful to various basic scientific fields, this project be fundamental to the greater understanding of plant sciences in southern Illinois and the surrounding regions. It will also provide information for more applied fields, such as natural area conservation, ecosystem restoration, and ecological impacts of human activities. On a local level, the digital resources will be integrated into courses at SIU, used in outreach activities at university sponsored events and in a local nature recreation park, and promoted to the general public.

The herbarium at SIU will digitize the collection to gather and provide label transcriptions, georeferences, and specimen imaging online as part of the Southeast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections (SERNEC). The flora of southern Illinois is closely allied to the southeastern US floristically. This project will proceed with a pre-digitization check of specimens, followed by barcoding, verification of label data, label transcription, digital imaging, image editing, and georeferencing. Finally, data will be transferred to SERNEC for public access, and added to the national resource at iDigBio.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From September 2020 to August 2024, the SIU Herbarium, an institute involved in the cataloguing of plants with a focus on southern Illinois, digitized the plant specimen collection held at Southern Illinois University. During this time, we digitized 90,741 specimens, including label records (identification, locality, date of collection, and collector information) and images of specimens. These data have become available on the online portal SERNEC. As a consequence, the digitized resources produced have enriched our understanding of the flora of the southeastern US, but especially southern Illinois.

During these four years, 12 undergraduate students and 3 graduate students have been employed and involved directly in the development and implementation of this project. Many have gone on to graduate school or permanent positions with help from the training they received during their work in the herbarium. We produced 12 videos on herbarium curatorial processes during this time period in order to train our own student employees; those videos have received over 4,000 views, so they have had a much more extensive impact on the herbarium curation community than expected. Likewise, the project has had a beneficial synergism with at least 4 classes taught at SIU where the importance of herbarium data and herbarium curation has been highlighted for students.

We have trained a cohort of students and can already see the beneficial impact this training has had on their careers. We expect that the 90,741 digitized records that are now available on SERNEC from the SIU herbarium will significantly contribute to the botanical sciences both locally and internationally. These digital data have a huge potential for improving the understanding of plant distribution, flowering times and for the very nature of plant taxonomy.
